content: I just made a port of Entity Tokens. TO keep the history, I just renamed the folder from Entity to Entity Tokens, and deleted all files except the two necessary ones. But Entity has lots of history. I've seen many suggestions to use filter-branch to remove an individual file history, but none that shows how to remove ALL history except a specific file (two files in this case. Any recommendations?
This might be different to what you're asking, but maybe not... https://gbayer.com/development/moving-files-from-one-git-repository-to-another-preserving-history/

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21213001/how-to-remove-all-traces-of-a-single-file-in-git

How to remove all traces of a single file in git
I recently noticed that I had a file with sensitive information under version control in git. I have now added this file to my .gitignore list, but how can I remove all mention of it from my commit
@Geoff St. Pierre (serundeputy) thats the opposite of what I need actually.
Not a single file but everything else except
sorry misunderstood; looks like Bwpandas is the opposite of mine so that should work?
I think @BWPanda (Peter) might be on to someting
when I'm more awake will try it.

I found and used those instructions when I exported the Tugboat module from BackdropCMS.org's repo and made it its own repo: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/tugboat

backdrop-contrib/tugboat
Integrates with Tugboat.qa to allow creating on-the-fly preview sites. - backdrop-contrib/tugboat
